question: A research group has developed a low-cost diagnostic retinal imaging device for cytomegalovirus retinitis in a population of HIV-infected patients. In a pilot study of 50 patients, the imaging test detected the presence of CMV retinitis in 50% of the patients. An ophthalmologist slit lamp examination, which was performed for each patient to serve as the gold standard for diagnosis, confirmed a diagnosis of CMV retinitis in 20 patients that were found to be positive through imaging, as well as 1 patient who tested negative with the device. If the prevalence of CMV retinitis in the population decreases due to increased access to antiretroviral therapy, how will positive predictive value and negative predictive value of the diagnostic test be affected?
predict: To analyze the effect of a decrease in prevalence on the positive predictive value (PPV) and negative predictive value (NPV) of the diagnostic test, we need to understand what these terms represent: - Positive Predictive Value (PPV): The proportion of true positive results among all positive results (true positives + false positives). - Negative Predictive Value (NPV): The proportion of true negative results among all negative results (true negatives + false negatives). Initially, in the pilot study: - Prevalence of CMV retinitis = 50% (50 out of 100 patients) - True positives (TP) = 20 (patients confirmed positive with both imaging and slit lamp examination) - False positives (FP) = 1 (patient tested positive with imaging but negative with slit lamp examination) - True negatives (TN) = 39 (patients tested negative with both imaging and slit lamp examination) - False negatives (FN) = 30 (patients tested negative with imaging but positive with slit lamp examination) PPV = TP / (TP + FP) = 20 / (20 + 1) = 0.9524 NPV = TN / (TN + FN) = 39 / (39 + 30) = 0.565 Now, if the prevalence of CMV retinitis decreases due to increased access to antiretroviral therapy, the number of true positives (TP) will decrease, and the number of false negatives (FN) will increase. Let's assume a hypothetical scenario where the new prevalence is 20% (20 out of 100 patients). To maintain the same number of true positives (20), the number of false positives (FP) and false negatives (FN) will increase. - New TP = 20 - New FP = 2 (assuming the same number of false positives as before) - New FN = 40 (assuming the same number of false negatives as before) - New TN = 60 (patients tested negative with both imaging and slit lamp examination) PPV = TP / (TP + FP) = 20 / (20 + 2) = 0.9091 NPV = TN / (TN + FN) = 60 / (60 + 40) = 0.600 Comparing the initial and new values: - PPV decreases from 0.9524 to 0.9091 - NPV decreases from 0.565 to 0.600 Therefore, the positive predictive value (PPV) decreases, and the negative predictive value (NPV) increases when the prevalence of CMV retinitis decreases due to increased access to antiretroviral therapy.
